isis.stitle: ELECTRONIC ENGINE CONTROLS - DETROIT DIESEL SERIES 60 - 1992 - 1993 - SYSTEM COMPONENTS AND OPERATION - ENGINE PROTECTION SYSTEM

svcprocinfo.para: Each Series 60 engine includes a standard engine protection system to prevent engine damage. All International installed Series 60 engines can be programmed to one of two modes of operation. The DEFAULT (standard) setting is for warning lights only.
The optional method is the Engine Power Reduction/Shutdown Feature. This feature includes warning lights, engine derating and engine shutdown.
The programmable parameter sheet included in the "Drivers Information Package" with this truck indicates which mode of engine protection this vehicle is programmed for.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Protection System
svcsubproc.para: Series 60 equipped vehicles have a yellow Check Engine Light (CEL) and a red Stop Engine Light (SEL) located in the telltale lights in the instrument cluster. Each time the key switch is turned to the ON position, the CEL and SEL lights will come on for several seconds as a system self-test and then go out.
If the lights remain on, it means that the ECM has detected a problem. A diagnostic check may be performed using the "Diagnostic ON/OFF Switch." See TROUBLESHOOTING.

Either of the two engine protection systems will: If during vehicle operation (or when starting the vehicle), any of the above inputs goes outside of a limit set by Detroit Diesel, both the yellow CEL and red SEL will be turned ON.

If the optional Engine Power Reduction/ Shutdown feature is enabled (customer selected) and one of the three monitored parameters goes outside the limits, the warning lights will turn ON and the engine power will gradually be reduced until the engine is shutdown 30 seconds later. There is a Shutdown Override switch which, when momentarily held in the ON position, provides an additional 30 seconds of engine operation to allow the vehicle to be brought to a safe stop.

svcsubproc.title: Yellow Check Engine Light (CEL)
svcsubproc.para: If the yellow "Check Engine Light" (CEL) remains on, it means the ECM has detected a problem. Take the vehicle to a service center as soon as possible.Some engine features may be lost while the light is on.

The CEL receives ignition power from the 5 amp fuse F6 and is grounded through an ECM controlled ground at terminal B1. The ECM "enables" or "disables" the ground (turning CEL ON or OFF) by applying 12 volts or 0 volts to terminal B1, depending on engine conditions. With terminal B1 LOW (zero volts), the CEL is turned ON.

svcsubproc.title: Red Stop Engine Light (SEL)
svcsubproc.para: If the red "Stop Engine Light" (SEL) comes on while operating the vehicle, the vehicle should be brought to a safe stop and the engine SHUT DOWN.

The red SEL receives power from 5 amp fuse F6 and is grounded through an ECM controlled ground at terminal B2. The ECM "enables" or "disables" the ground by applying 12 volts or 0 volts to terminal B2, depending on engine conditions. With terminal B2 LOW (zero volts), the SEL is turned ON.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Override Switch (366)
svcsubproc.para: The normally open, momentary ON, engine override switch receives a signal from ECM terminal G1. Momentarily closing this switch completes the ground path through the ECM power connector, pulling ECM terminal G1 to ground. The ECM senses the change in voltage at terminal G1 and provides 30 seconds of additional engine run time.

caution.para: Using the override switch excessively may cause additional damage to occur. Use the engine override only in an emergency.

svcsubproc.title: DDEC Low Coolant Module (371) And Probe (363)
svcsubproc.para: The DDEC coolant module (installed by International) is connected to the International engine harness at connector (371). Circuit 34B/97D provides ignition power from F28, 10 amp fuse, to the DDEC coolant module terminal (5). The module is grounded from terminal (3), on circuit 34-G, through the ECM power cable.

Low Coolant Module, terminal 1, sends a very low current signal on circuit 34 to the internally grounded Low Coolant Probe. When coolant level is above the probe, the signal is conducted through the probe to ground on circuit 34-G. If the coolant level is below the probe (for several seconds to prevent false signals from sloshing) the probe circuit is open, which is detected by the Low Coolant Module and a signal is sent to the ECM. The ECM then activates the Engine Protection system.

Low Coolant Module signal terminal (4) is connected by circuit 34A to ECM terminal H3. The ECM can receive several different signals from the Low Coolant Module including one signal when coolant is above the probe and another signal when coolant is below the probe. Additionally the ECM monitors (using signals on 34A) voltage levels it uses in setting diagnostic fault codes. This manual does not recommend trying to bench test the DDEC coolant module using an ohmmeter as internal circuits may be damaged.
